play.title: The firﬅ Part of Henry the Sixt.

persona.persname: General of the French Force at Bordeaux

scene.stagedir: Enter the Funerall of King Henry the Fift, attended on by the Duke of Bedford, Regent of France; the Duke of Gloſter, Proteor; the Duke of Exeter Warwicke, the Biſhop of Wincheſter, and the Duke of Somerſet.

speech.speaker: Bedford.
speech.line: Hvng be ý heauens with black, yield day to night;
Comets importing change of Times and States,
Brandiſh your cryſtall Treſſes in the Skie,
And with them ſcourge the bad reuolting Stars,
That haue conſented vnto Henries death:
King Henry the Fift, too famous to liue long,
England ne’re loſt a King of ſo much worth.

speech.speaker: Gloſt.
speech.line: England ne’re had a King vntill his time:
Vertue he had, deſeruing to command,
His brandiſht Sword did blinde men with his beames,
His Armes ſpred wider then a Dragons Wings:
His ſparkling Eyes, repleat with wrathfull ﬁre,
More dazled and droue back his Enemies,
Then mid-day Sunne, ﬁerce bent againſt their faces.
What ſhould I ſay? his Deeds exceed all ſpeech:
He ne’re lift vp his Hand, but conquered.

speech.speaker: Exe.
speech.line: We mourne in black, why mourn we not in blood?
Henry is dead, and neuer ſhall reuiue:
Vpon a Woodden Cofﬁn we attend;
And Deaths diſhonourable Viorie,
We with our ſtately preſence gloriﬁe,
Like Captiues bound to a Triumphant Carre.
What? ſhall we curſe the Planets of Miſhap,
That plotted thus our Glories ouerthrow?
Or ſhall we thinke the ſubtile-witted French,
Coniurers and Sorcerers, that afraid of him,
By Magick Verſes haue contriu’d his end.

speech.speaker: Winch.
speech.line: He was a King, bleſt of the King of Kings.
Vnto the French, the dreadfull Iudgement-Day
So dreadfull will not be, as was his ſight.
The Battailes of the Lord of Hoſts he fought:
The Churches Prayers made him ſo proſperous.

speech.speaker: Gloſt.
speech.line: The Church? where is it?
Had not Church-men pray’d,
His thred of Life had not ſo ſoone decay’d.
None doe you like, but an effeminate Prince,
Whom like a Schoole-boy you may ouer-awe.

speech.speaker: Winch.
speech.line: Gloſter, what ere we like, thou art Proteor,
And lookeſt to command the Prince and Realme.
Thy Wife is prowd, ſhe holdeth thee in awe,
More then God or Religious Church-men may.

speech.speaker: Gloſt.
speech.line: Name not Religion, for thou lou’ſt the Fleſh,
And ne’re throughout the yeere to Church thou go’ſt,
Except it be to pray againſt thy foes.

speech.speaker: Bed.
speech.line: Ceaſe, ceaſe theſe Iarres, & reſt your minds in peace:
Let’s to the Altar: Heralds wayt on vs;
In ſtead of Gold, wee’le offer vp our Armes,
Since Armes auayle not, now that Henry’s dead,
Poſteritie await for wretched yeeres,
When at their Mothers moiſtned eyes, Babes ſhall ſuck,
Our Ile be made a Nouriſh of ſalt Teares,
And none but Women left to wayle the dead.
Henry the Fift, thy Ghoſt I inuocate:
Proſper this Realme, keepe it from Ciuill Broyles,
Combat with aduerſe Planets in the Heauens;
A farre more glorious Starre thy Soule will make,
Then Iulius Cæſar, or bright —

speech.speaker: Meſſ.
speech.line: My honourable Lords, health to you all:
Sad tidings bring I to you out of France,
Of loſſe, of ſlaughter, and diſcomﬁture:
Guyen, Champaigne, Rheimes, Orleance,
Paris Guyſors, Poiiers, are all quite loſt.

speech.speaker: Bedf.
speech.line: What ſay’ſt thou man, before dead Henry’s Coarſe?
Speake ſoftly, or the loſſe of thoſe great Townes
Will make him burſt his Lead, and riſe from death.

speech.speaker: Glost.
speech.line: Is Paris loſt? is Roan yeelded vp?
If Henry were recall’d to life againe,
Theſe news would cauſe him once more yeeld the Ghoſt.

speech.speaker: Exe.
speech.line: How were they loſt? what trecherie was vs’d?

speech.speaker: Meſſ.
speech.line: No trecherie, but want of Men and Money.
Amongſt the Souldiers this is muttered,
That here you maintaine ſeuerall Faions:
And whil’ſt a Field ſhould be diſpatcht and fought,
You are diſputing of your Generals.
One would haue lingring Warres, with little coſt;
Another would ﬂye ſwift, but wanteth Wings:
A third thinkes, without expence at all,
By guilefull faire words, Peace may be obtayn’d.
Awake, awake, Engliſh Nobilitie,
Let not ſlouth dimme your Honors, new begot;
Cropt are the Flower-de-Luces in your Armes
Of Englands Coat, one halfe is cut away.

speech.speaker: Exe.
speech.line: Were our Teares wanting to this Funerall,
Theſe Tidings would call forth her ﬂowing Tides.

speech.speaker: Bedf.
speech.line: Me they concerne, Regent I am of France:
Giue me my ſteeled Coat, Ile ﬁght for France.
Away with theſe diſgracefull wayling Robes;
Wounds will I lend the French, in ſtead of Eyes,
To weepe their intermiſſiue Miſeries.

speech.speaker: Meſſ.
speech.line: Lords view theſe Letters, full of bad miſchance.
France is reuolted from the Engliſh quite,
Except ſome petty Townes, of no import.
The Dolphin Charles is crowned King in Rheimes:
The Baſtard of Orleance with him is ioyn’d:
Reynold, Duke of Aniou, doth take his part,
The Duke of Alanſon ﬂyeth to his ſide.

speech.speaker: Exe.
speech.line: The Dolphin crown’d King? all ﬂye to him?
O whither ſhall we ﬂye from this reproach?

speech.speaker: Gloſt.
speech.line: We will not ﬂye, but to our enemies throats.
Bedford, if thou be ſlacke, Ile ﬁght it out.

speech.speaker: Bed.
speech.line: Gloſter, why doubtſt thou of my forwardneſſe?
An Army haue I muſter’d in my thoughts,
Wherewith already France is ouer-run.

speech.speaker: Meſ.
speech.line: My gracious Lords, to adde to your laments,
Wherewith you now bedew King Henries hearſe,
I muſt informe you of a diſmall ﬁght,
Betwixt the ſtout Lord Talbot, and the French.

speech.speaker: Win.
speech.line: What? wherein Talbot ouercame, is’t ſo?

speech.speaker: 3. Meſ.
speech.line: O no: wherein Lord Talbot was o’rethrown:
The circumſtance Ile tell you more at large.
The tenth of Auguſt laſt, this dreadfull Lord,
Retyring from the Siege of Orleance,
Hauing full ſcarce ſix thouſand in his troupe,
By three and twentie thouſand of the French
Was round incompaſſed, and ſet vpon:
No leyſure had he to enranke his men.
He wanted Pikes to ſet before his Archers:
In ſtead whereof, ſharpe Stakes pluckt out of Hedges
They pitched in the ground confuſedly,
To keepe the Horſemen off, from breaking in.
More then three houres the ﬁght continued:
Where valiant Talbot, aboue humane thought,
Enaed wonders with his Sword and Lance.
Hundreds he ſent to Hell; and none durſt ſtand him:
Here, there, and euery where enrag’d, he ſlew.
The French exclaym’d, the Deuill was in Armes,
All the whole Army ſtood agaz’d on him.
His Souldiers ſpying his vndaunted Spirit,
A Talbot, a Talbot, cry’d out amaine,
And ruſht into the Bowels of the Battaile.
Here had the Conqueſt fully been ſeal’d vp,
If Sir Iohn Falſtaﬀe had not play’d the Coward.
He being in the Vauward, plac’t behinde,
With purpoſe to relieue and follow them,
Cowardly ﬂed, not hauing ſtruck one ſtroake.
Hence grew the generall wrack and maſſacre:
Encloſed were they with their Enemies.
A baſe Wallon, to win the Dolphins grace,
Thruſt Talbot with a Speare into the Back,
Whom all France, with their chiefe aſſembled ſtrength,
Durſt not preſume to looke once in the face.

speech.speaker: Bedf.
speech.line: Is Talbot ſlaine then? I will ſlay my ſelfe,
For liuing idly here, in pompe and eaſe,
Whil’ſt ſuch a worthy Leader, wanting ayd,
Vnto his daſtard foe-men is betray’d.

speech.speaker: 3. Meſſ.
speech.line: O no, he liues, but is tooke Priſoner,
And Lord Scales with him, and Lord Hungerford:
Moſt of the reſt ſlaughter’d, or tooke likewiſe.

speech.speaker: Bedf.
speech.line: His Ranſome there is none but I ſhall pay.
Ile hale the Dolphin headlong from his Throne,
His Crowne ſhall be the Ranſome of my friend:
Foure of their Lords Ile change for one of ours.
Farwell my Maſters, to my Taske will I,
Bonﬁres in France forthwith I am to make,
To keepe our great Saint Georges Feaſt withall.
Ten thouſand Souldiers with me I will take,
Whoſe bloody deeds ſhall make all Europe quake.

speech.speaker: 3. Meſſ.
speech.line: So you had need, for Orleance is beſieg’d,
The Engliſh Army is growne weake and faint:
The Earle of Salisbury craueth ſupply,
And hardly keepes his men from mutinie,
Since they ſo few, watch ſuch a multitude.

speech.speaker: Exe.
speech.line: Remember Lords your Oathes to Henry ſworne:
Eyther to quell the Dolphin vtterly,
Or bring him in obedience to your yoake.

speech.speaker: Bedf.
speech.line: I doe remember it, and here take my leaue,
To goe about my preparation.

speech.speaker: Gloſt.
speech.line: Ile to the Tower with all the haſt I can,
To view th’ Artillerie and Munition,
And then I will proclayme young Henry King.

speech.speaker: Exe.
speech.line: To Eltam will I, where the young King is,
Being ordayn’d his ſpeciall Gouernor,
And for his ſafetie there Ile beſt deuiſe.

speech.speaker: Winch.
speech.line: Each hath his Place and Funion to attend:
I am left out; for me nothing remaines:
But long I will not be Iack out of Ofﬁce.
The King from Eltam I intend to ſend,
And ſit at chiefeſt Sterne of publique Weale.

scene.stagedir: Enter Charles, Alanſon, and Reigneir, marching with Drum and Souldiers.

speech.speaker: Charles.
speech.line: Mars his true mouing, euen as in the Heauens,
So in the Earth, to this day is not knowne.
Late did he ſhine vpon the Engliſh ſide:
Now we are Viors, vpon vs he ſmiles.
What Townes of any moment, but we haue?
At pleaſure here we lye, neere Orleance:
Otherwhiles, the famiſht Engliſh, like pale Ghoſts,
Faintly beſiege vs one houre in a moneth.

speech.speaker: Alan.
speech.line: They want their Porredge, & their fat Bul Beeues:
Eyther they muſt be dyeted like Mules,
And haue their Prouender ty’d to their mouthes,
Or pitteous they will looke, like drowned Mice.

speech.speaker: Reigneir.
speech.line: Let’s rayſe the Siege: why liue we idly here?
Talbot is taken, whom we wont to feare:
Remayneth none but mad-brayn’d Salisbury,
And he may well in fretting ſpend his gall,
Nor men nor Money hath he to make Warre.

speech.speaker: Charles.
speech.line: Sound, ſound Alarum, we will ruſh on them.
Now for the honour of the forlorne French:
Him I forgiue my death, that killeth me,
When he ſees me goe back one foot, or ﬂye.

scene.stagedir: Here Alarum, they are beaten back by the Engliſh, with great loſſe.

speech.speaker: Charles.
speech.line: Who euer ſaw the like? what men haue I?
Dogges, Cowards, Daſtards: I would ne’re haue ﬂed,
But that they left me ’midſt my Enemies.

speech.speaker: Reigneir.
speech.line: Salisbury is a deſperate Homicide,
He ﬁghteth as one weary of his life:
The other Lords, like Lyons wanting foode,
Doe ruſh vpon vs as their hungry prey.

speech.speaker: Alanſon.
speech.line: Froyſard, a Countreyman of ours, records,
England all Oliuers and Rowlands breed,
During the time Edward the third did raigne:
More truly now may this be veriﬁed;
For none but Samſons and Goliaſſes
It ſendeth forth to skirmiſh: one to tenne?
Leane raw-bon’d Raſcals, who would e’er ſuppoſe,
They had ſuch courage and audacitie?

speech.speaker: Charles.
speech.line: Let’s leaue this Towne,
For they are hayre-brayn’d Slaues,
And hunger will enforce them to be more eager:
Of old I know them; rather with their Teeth
The Walls they’le teare downe, then forſake the Siege.

speech.speaker: Reigneir.
speech.line: I thinke by ſome odde Gimmors or Deuice
Their Armes are ſet, like Clocks, ſtill to ſtrike on;
Elſe ne’re could they hold out ſo as they doe:
By my conſent, wee’le euen let them alone.

speech.speaker: Alanſon.
speech.line: Be it ſo.

speech.speaker: Baſtard.
speech.line: Where’s the Prince Dolphin? I haue newes
for him.

speech.speaker: Dolph.
speech.line: Baſtard of Orleance, thrice welcome to vs.

speech.speaker: Baſt.
speech.line: Me thinks your looks are ſad, your chear appal’d.
Hath the late ouerthrow wrought this offence?
Be not diſmay’d, for ſuccour is at hand:
A holy Maid hither with me I bring,
Which by a Viſion ſent to her from Heauen,
Ordayned is to rayſe this tedious Siege,
And driue the Engliſh forth the bounds of France:
The ſpirit of deepe Prophecie ſhe hath,
Exceeding the nine Sibyls of old Rome:
What’s paſt, and what’s to come, ſhe can deſcry.
Speake, ſhall I call her in? beleeue my words,
For they are certaine, and vnfallible.

speech.speaker: Dolph.
speech.line: Goe call her in: but ﬁrſt, to try her skill,
Reignier ſtand thou as Dolphin in my place;
Queſtion her prowdly, let thy Lookes be ſterne,
By this meanes ſhall we ſound what skill ſhe hath.

speech.speaker: Reigneir.
speech.line: Faire Maid, is’t thou wilt doe theſe won —
drous feats?

speech.speaker: Puzel.
speech.line: Reignier, is’t thou that thinkeſt to beguile me?
Where is the Dolphin? Come, come from behinde,
I know thee well, though neuer ſeene before.
Be not amaz’d, there’s nothing hid from me;
In priuate will I talke with thee apart:
Stand back you Lords, and giue vs leaue a while.

speech.speaker: Reigneir.
speech.line: She takes vpon her brauely at ﬁrſt daſh.

speech.speaker: Puzel.
speech.line: Dolphin, I am by birth a Shepheards Daughter,
My wit vntrayn’d in any kind of Art:
Heauen and our Lady gracious hath it pleas’d
To ſhine on my contemptible eſtate.
Loe, whileſt I wayted on my tender Lambes,
And to Sunnes parching heat diſplay’d my cheekes,
Gods Mother deigned to appeare to me,
And in a Viſion full of Maieſtie,
Will’d me to leaue my baſe Vocation,
And free my Countrey from Calamitie:
Her ayde ſhe promis’d, and aſſur’d ſucceſſe.
In compleat Glory ſhee reueal’d her ſelfe:
And whereas I was black and ſwart before,
With thoſe cleare Rayes, which ſhee infus’d on me,
That beautie am I bleſt with, which you may ſee.
Aske me what queſtion thou canſt poſſible,
And I will anſwer vnpremeditated:
My Courage trie by Combat, if thou dar’ſt,
And thou ſhalt ﬁnde that I exceed my Sex.
Reſolue on this, thou ſhalt be fortunate,
If thou receiue me for thy Warlike Mate.

speech.speaker: Dolph.
speech.line: Thou haſt aſtoniſht me with thy high termes:
Onely this proofe Ile of thy Valour make,
In ſingle Combat thou ſhalt buckle with me;
And if thou vanquiſheſt, thy words are true,
Otherwiſe I renounce all conﬁdence.

speech.speaker: Puzel.
speech.line: I am prepar’d: here is my keene-edg’d Sword,
Deckt with ﬁne Flower-de-Luces on each ſide,
The which at Touraine, in S. Katherines Church-yard,
Out of a great deale of old Iron, I choſe forth.

speech.speaker: Dolph.
speech.line: Then come a Gods name, I feare no woman.

speech.speaker: Puzel.
speech.line: And while I liue, Ile ne’re ﬂye from a man.

scene.stagedir: Here they ﬁght, and Ioane de Puzel ouercomes.

speech.speaker: Dolph.
speech.line: Stay, ſtay thy hands, thou art an Amazon,
And ﬁghteſt with the Sword of Debora.

speech.speaker: Puzel.
speech.line: Chriſts Mother helpes me, elſe I were too
weake.

speech.speaker: Dolph.
speech.line: Who e’re helps thee, ‘tis thou that muſt help me:
Impatiently I burne with thy deſire,
My heart and hands thou haſt at once ſubdu’d.
Excellent Puzel, if thy name be ſo,
Let me thy ſeruant, and not Soueraigne be,
‘Tis the French Dolphin ſueth to thee thus.

speech.speaker: Puzel.
speech.line: I muſt not yeeld to any rights of Loue,
For my Profeſſion’s ſacred from aboue:
When I haue chaſed all thy Foes from hence,
Then will I thinke vpon a recompence.

speech.speaker: Dolph.
speech.line: Meane time looke gracious on thy proſtrate
Thrall.

speech.speaker: Reigneir.
speech.line: My Lord me thinkes is very long in talke.

speech.speaker: Alanſ.
speech.line: Doubtleſſe he ſhriues this woman to her ſmock,
Elſe ne’re could he ſo long protra his ſpeech.

speech.speaker: Reigneir.
speech.line: Shall wee diſturbe him, ſince hee keepes no
meane?

speech.speaker: Alan.
speech.line: He may meane more then we poor men do know,
Theſe women are ſhrewd tempters with their tongues.

speech.speaker: Reigneir.
speech.line: My Lord, where are you? what deuiſe you on?
Shall we giue o’re Orleance, or no?

speech.speaker: Puzel.
speech.line: Why no, I ſay: diſtruſtfull Recreants,
Fight till the laſt gaſpe: Ile be your guard.

speech.speaker: Dolph.
speech.line: What ſhee ſayes, Ile conﬁrme: wee’le ﬁght
it out.

speech.speaker: Puzel.
speech.line: Aſſign’d am I to be the Engliſh Scourge.
This night the Siege aſſuredly Ile rayſe:
Expe Saint Martins Summer, Halcyons dayes,
Since I haue entred into theſe Warres.
Glory is like a Circle in the Water,
Which neuer ceaſeth to enlarge it ſelfe,
Till by broad ſpreading, it diſperſe to naught.
With Henries death, the Engliſh Circle ends,
Diſperſed are the glories it included:
Now am I like that prowd inſulting Ship,
Which Cæſar and his fortune bare at once.

speech.speaker: Dolph.
speech.line: Was Mahomet inſpired with a Doue?
Thou with an Eagle art inſpired then.
Helen, the Mother of Great Conſtantine,
Nor yet S. Philips daughters were like thee.
Bright Starre of Venus, falne downe on the Earth,
How may I reuerently worſhip thee enough?

speech.speaker: Alanſon.
speech.line: Leaue off delayes, and let vs rayſe the
Siege.

speech.speaker: Reigneir.
speech.line: Woman, do what thou canſt to ſaue our honors,
Driue them from Orleance, and be immortaliz’d.

speech.speaker: Dolph.
speech.line: Preſently wee’le try: come, let’s away about it,
No Prophet will I truſt, if ſhee proue falſe.

speech.speaker: Gloſt.
speech.line: I am come to ſuruey the Tower this day;
Since Henries death, I feare there is Conueyance:
Where be theſe Warders, that they wait not here?
Open the Gates, ‘tis Gloſter that calls.

speech.speaker: 1. Warder.
speech.line: Who’s there, that knocks ſo imperiouſly?

speech.speaker: Gloſt. 1. Man.
speech.line: It is the Noble Duke of Gloſter.

speech.speaker: 2. Warder.
speech.line: Who ere he be, you may not be let in.

speech.speaker: 1. Man.
speech.line: Villaines, anſwer you ſo the Lord Proteor?

speech.speaker: 1. Warder.
speech.line: The Lord prote him, ſo we anſwer him,
We doe no otherwiſe then wee are will’d.

speech.speaker: Glost.
speech.line: Who willed you? or whoſe will ſtands but mine?
There’s none Proteor of the Realme, but I:
Breake vp the Gates, Ile be your warrantize;
Shall I be ﬂowted thus by dunghill Groomes?

scene.stagedir: Gloſters men ruſh at the Tower Gates, and Wooduile the Lieutenant ſpeakes within.

speech.speaker: Wooduile.
speech.line: What noyſe is this? what Traytors haue
wee here?

speech.speaker: Glost.
speech.line: Lieutenant, is it you whoſe voyce I heare?
Open the Gates, here’s Gloſter that would enter.

speech.speaker: Wooduile.
speech.line: Haue patience Noble Duke, I may not open,
The Cardinall of Wincheſter forbids:
From him I haue expreſſe commandement,
That thou nor none of thine ſhall be let in.

speech.speaker: Gloſt.
speech.line: Faint-hearted Wooduile, prizeſt him ’fore me?
Arrogant Wincheſter, that haughtie Prelate,
Whom Henry our late Soueraigne ne’re could brooke?
Thou art no friend to God, or to the King:
Open the Gates, or Ile ſhut thee out ſhortly.

speech.speaker: Seruingmen.
speech.line: Open the Gates vnto the Lord Proteor,
Or wee’le burſt them open, if that you come not quickly.

scene.stagedir: Enter to the Proteor at the Tower Gates, Wincheſter and his men in Tawney Coates.

speech.speaker: Winchest.
speech.line: How now ambitious Vmpheir, what meanes
this?

speech.speaker: Gloſt.
speech.line: Piel’d Prieſt, doo’ſt thou command me to be
ſhut out?

speech.speaker: Winch.
speech.line: I doe, thou moſt vſurping Proditor,
And not Proteor of the King or Realme.

speech.speaker: Gloſt.
speech.line: Stand back thou manifeſt Conſpirator,
Thou that contriued’ſt to murther our dead Lord,
Thou that giu’ſt Whores Indulgences to ſinne,
Ile canuas thee in thy broad Cardinalls Hat,
If thou proceed in this thy inſolence.

speech.speaker: Winch.
speech.line: Nay, ſtand thou back, I will not budge a foot:
This be Damaſcus, be thou curſed Cain,
To ſlay thy Brother Abel, if thou wilt.

speech.speaker: Gloſt.
speech.line: I will not ſlay thee, but Ile driue thee back:
Thy Scarlet Robes, as a Childs bearing Cloth,
Ile vſe, to carry thee out of this place.

speech.speaker: Winch.
speech.line: Doe what thou dar’ſt, I beard thee to thy
face.

speech.speaker: Gloſt.
speech.line: What? am I dar’d, and bearded to my face?
Draw men, for all this priuiledged place,
Blew Coats to Tawny Coats. Prieſt, beware your Beard,
I meane to tugge it, and to cuffe you ſoundly.
Vnder my feet I ſtampe thy Cardinalls Hat:
In ſpight of Pope, or dignities of Church,
Here by the Cheekes Ile drag thee vp and downe.

speech.speaker: Winch.
speech.line: Gloſter, thou wilt anſwere this before the
Pope.

speech.speaker: Gloſt.
speech.line: Wincheſter Gooſe, I cry, a Rope, a Rope.
Now beat them hence, why doe you let them ſtay?
Thee Ile chaſe hence, thou Wolfe in Sheepes array.
Out Tawney-Coates, out Scarlet Hypocrite.

scene.stagedir: Here Gloſters men beat out the Cardinalls men, and enter in the hurly-burly the Maior of London, and his Oﬃcers.

speech.speaker: Maior.
speech.line: Fye Lords, that you being ſupreme Magiſtrates,
Thus contumeliouſly ſhould breake the Peace.

speech.speaker: Gloſt.
speech.line: Peace Maior, thou know’ſt little of my wrongs:
Here’s Beauford, that regards nor God nor King,
Hath here diſtrayn’d the Tower to his vſe.

speech.speaker: Winch.
speech.line: Here’s Gloſter, a Foe to Citizens,
One that ſtill motions Warre, and neuer Peace,
O’re-charging your free Purſes with large Fines;
That ſeekes to ouerthrow Religion,
Becauſe he is Proteor of the Realme;
And would haue Armour here out of the Tower,
To Crowne himſelfe King, and ſuppreſſe the Prince.

speech.speaker: Gloſt.
speech.line: I will not anſwer thee with words, but blowes.

speech.speaker: Maior.
speech.line: Naught reſts for me, in this tumultuous ſtrife,
But to make open Proclamation.
Come Ofﬁcer, as lowd as e’re thou canſt, cry:

line.recite: All manner of men, aſſembled here in Armes this day,
againſt Gods Peace and the Kings, wee charge and command
you, in his Highneſſe Name, to repayre to your ſeuerall dwel-
ling places, and not to weare, handle, or vſe any Sword, Wea-
pon, or Dagger hence-forward, vpon paine of death.

speech.speaker: Gloſt.
speech.line: Cardinall, Ile be no breaker of the Law:
But we ſhall meet, and breake our minds at large.

speech.speaker: Winch.
speech.line: Gloſter, wee’le meet to thy coſt, be ſure:
Thy heart-blood I will haue for this dayes worke.

speech.speaker: Maior.
speech.line: Ile call for Clubs, if you will not away:
This Cardinall’s more haughtie then the Deuill.

speech.speaker: Gloſt.
speech.line: Maior farewell: thou doo’ſt but what thou
may’ſt.

speech.speaker: Winch.
speech.line: Abhominable Gloſter, guard thy Head,
For I intend to haue it ere long.

speech.speaker: Maior.
speech.line: See the Coaſt clear’d, and then we will depart.
Good God, theſe Nobles ſhould ſuch ſtomacks beare,
I my ſelfe ﬁght not once in fortie yeere.

scene.stagedir: Enter the Maſter Gunner of Orleance, and his Boy.

speech.speaker: M. Gunner.
speech.line: Sirrha, thou know’ſt how Orleance is beſieg’d,
And how the Engliſh haue the Suburbs wonne.

speech.speaker: Boy.
speech.line: Father I know, and oft haue ſhot at them,
How e’re vnfortunate, I miſs’d my ayme.

speech.speaker: M. Gunner.
speech.line: But now thou ſhalt not. Be thou rul’d by me:
Chiefe Maſter Gunner am I of this Towne,
Something I muſt doe to procure me grace:
The Princes eſpyals haue informed me,
How the Engliſh, in the Suburbs cloſe entrencht,
Went through a ſecret Grate of Iron Barres,
In yonder Tower, to ouer-peere the Citie,
And thence diſcouer, how with moſt aduantage
They may vex vs with Shot or with Aſſault.
To intercept this inconuenience,
A Peece of Ordnance ’gainſt it I haue plac’d,
And euen theſe three dayes haue I watcht,
If I could ſee them. Now doe thou watch,
For I can ſtay no longer.
If thou ſpy’ſt any, runne and bring me word,
And thou ſhalt ﬁnde me at the Gouernors.

speech.speaker: Boy.
speech.line: Father, I warrant you, take you no care,
Ile neuer trouble you, if I may ſpye them.

scene.stagedir: Enter Salisbury and Talbot on the Turrets, with others.

speech.speaker: Salisb.
speech.line: Talbot, my life, my ioy, againe return’d?
How wert thou handled, being Priſoner?
Or by what meanes got’s thou to be releas’d?
Diſcourſe I prethee on this Turrets top.

speech.speaker: Talbot.
speech.line: The Earle of Bedford had a Priſoner,
Call’d the braue Lord Ponton de Santrayle,
For him was I exchang’d, and ranſom’d.
But with a baſer man of Armes by farre,
Once in contempt they would haue barter’d me:
Which I diſdaining, ſcorn’d, and craued death,
Rather then I would be ſo pil’d eſteem’d:
In ﬁne, redeem’d I was as I deſir’d.
But O, the trecherous Falſtaﬀe wounds my heart,
Whom with my bare ﬁſts I would execute,
If I now had him brought into my power.

speech.speaker: Salisb.
speech.line: Yet tell’ſt thou not, how thou wert enter —
tain’d.

speech.speaker: Tal.
speech.line: With ſcoffes and ſcornes, and contumelious taunts,
In open Market-place produc’t they me,
To be a publique ſpeacle to all:
Here, ſayd they, is the Terror of the French,
The Scar-Crow that affrights our Children ſo.
Then broke I from the Ofﬁcers that led me,
And with my nayles digg’d ſtones out of the ground,
To hurle at the beholders of my ſhame.
My griſly countenance made others ﬂye,
None durſt come neere, for feare of ſuddaine death.
In Iron Walls they deem’d me not ſecure:
So great feare of my Name ’mongſt them were ſpread,
That they ſuppos’d I could rend Barres of Steele,
And ſpurne in pieces Poſts of Adamant.
Wherefore a guard of choſen Shot I had,
That walkt about me euery Minute while:
And if I did but ſtirre out of my Bed,
Ready they were to ſhoot me to the heart.

scene.stagedir: Enter the Boy with a Linſtock.

speech.speaker: Salisb.
speech.line: I grieue to heare what torments you endur’d,
But we will be reueng’d ſufﬁciently.
Now it is Supper time in Orleance:
Here, through this Grate, I count each one,
And view the Frenchmen how they fortiﬁe:
Let vs looke in, the ſight will much delight thee:
Sir Thomas Gargraue, and Sir William Glanſdale,
Let me haue your expreſſe opinions,
Where is beſt place to make our Batt’ry next?

speech.speaker: Gargraue.
speech.line: I thinke at the North Gate, for there ſtands
Lords.

speech.speaker: Glanſdale.
speech.line: And I heere, at the Bulwarke of the
Bridge.

speech.speaker: Talb.
speech.line: For ought I ſee, this Citie muſt be famiſht,
Or with light Skirmiſhes enfeebled.

scene.stagedir: Here they ſhot, and Salisbury falls downe.

speech.speaker: Salisb.
speech.line: O Lord haue mercy on vs, wretched ſinners.

speech.speaker: Gargraue.
speech.line: O Lord haue mercy on me, wofull man.

speech.speaker: Talb.
speech.line: What chance is this, that ſuddenly hath croſt vs?
Speake Salisbury; at leaſt, if thou canſt, ſpeake:
How far’ſt thou, Mirror of all Martiall men?
One of thy Eyes, and thy Cheekes ſide ſtruck off?
Accurſed Tower, accurſed fatall Hand,
That hath contriu’d this wofull Tragedie.
In thirteene Battailes, Salisbury o’recame:
Henry the Fift he ﬁrſt trayn’d to the Warres.
Whil’ſt any Trumpe did ſound, or Drum ſtruck vp,
His Sword did ne’re leaue ſtriking in the ﬁeld.
Yet liu’ſt thou Salisbury? though thy ſpeech doth fayle,
One Eye thou haſt to looke to Heauen for grace.
The Sunne with one Eye vieweth all the World.
Heauen be thou gracious to none aliue,
If Salisbury wants mercy at thy hands.
Beare hence his Body, I will helpe to bury it.
Sir Thomas Gargraue, haſt thou any life?
Speake vnto Talbot, nay, looke vp to him.
Salisbury cheare thy Spirit with this comfort,
Thou ſhalt not dye whiles —
He beckens with his hand, and ſmiles on me:
As who ſhould ſay, When I am dead and gone,
Remember to auenge me on the French.
Plantaginet I will, and like thee,
Play on the Lute, beholding the Townes burne:
Wretched ſhall France be onely in my Name.
speech.stagedir: Here an Alarum, and it Thunders and Lightens.
speech.line: What ſtirre is this? what tumult’s in the Heauens?
Whence commeth this Alarum, and the noyſe?

speech.speaker: Meſſ.
speech.line: My Lord, my Lord, the French haue gather’d head.
The Dolphin, with one Ioane de Puzel ioyn’d,
A holy Propheteſſe, new riſen vp,
Is come with a great Power, to rayſe the Siege.

scene.stagedir: Here Salisbury lifteth himſelfe vp, and groanes.

speech.speaker: Talb.
speech.line: Heare, heare, how dying Salisbury doth groane,
It irkes his heart he cannot be reueng’d.
Frenchmen, Ile be a Salisbury to you.
Puzel or Puſſel, Dolphin or Dog-ﬁſh,
Your hearts Ile ſtampe out with my Horſes heeles,
And make a Quagmire of your mingled braines.
Conuey me Salisbury into his Tent,
And then wee’le try what theſe daſtard Frenchmen dare.

scene.stagedir: Here an Alarum againe, and Talbot purſueth the Dolphin, and driueth him: Then enter Ioane de Puzel, driuing Engliſhmen before her. Then enter Talbot.

speech.speaker: Talb.
speech.line: Where is my ſtrength, my valour, and my force?
Our Engliſh Troupes retyre, I cannot ſtay them,
A Woman clad in Armour chaſeth them.
Here, here ſhee comes. Ile haue a bowt with thee:
Deuill, or Deuils Dam, Ile coniure thee:
Blood will I draw on thee, thou art a Witch,
And ſtraightway giue thy Soule to him thou ſeru’ſt.

speech.speaker: Puzel.
speech.line: Come, come, ‘tis onely I that muſt diſgrace
thee.

speech.speaker: Talb.
speech.line: Heauens, can you ſuffer Hell ſo to preuayle?
My breſt Ile burſt with ſtraining of my courage,
And from my ſhoulders crack my Armes aſunder,
But I will chaſtiſe this high-minded Strumpet.

speech.speaker: Puzel.
speech.line: Talbot farwell, thy houre is not yet come,
I muſt goe Viuall Orleance forthwith:
speech.stagedir: A ſhort Alarum: then enter the Towne with Souldiers.
speech.line: O’re-take me if thou canſt, I ſcorne thy ſtrength.
Goe, goe, cheare vp thy hungry-ſtarued men,
Helpe Salisbury to make his Teſtament,
This Day is ours, as many more ſhall be.

speech.speaker: Talb.
speech.line: My thoughts are whirled like a Potters Wheele,
I know not where I am, nor what I doe:
A Witch by feare, not force, like Hannibal,
Driues back our troupes, and conquers as ſhe liſts:
So Bees with ſmoake, and Doues with noyſome ſtench,
Are from their Hyues and Houſes driuen away.
They call’d vs, for our ﬁerceneſſe, Engliſh Dogges,
Now like to Whelpes, we crying runne away.
Hearke Countreymen, eyther renew the ﬁght,
Or teare the Lyons out of Englands Coat;
Renounce your Soyle, giue Sheepe in Lyons ſtead:
Sheepe run not halfe ſo trecherous from the Wolfe,
Or Horſe or Oxen from the Leopard,
As you ﬂye from your oft-subdued ſlaues.
It will not be, retyre into your Trenches:
You all conſented vnto Salisburies death,
For none would ſtrike a ſtroake in his reuenge.
Puzel is entred into Orleance,
In ſpight of vs, or ought that we could doe.
O would I were to dye with Salisbury,
The ſhame hereof, will make me hide my head.

scene.stagedir: Enter on the Walls, Puzel, Dolphin, Reigneir, Alanſon, and Souldiers.

speech.speaker: Puzel.
speech.line: Aduance our wauing Colours on the Walls,
Reſcu’d is Orleance from the Engliſh.
Thus Ioane de Puzel hath perform’d her word.

speech.speaker: Dolph.
speech.line: Diuineſt Creature, Aſtrea’s Daughter,
How ſhall I honour thee for this ſucceſſe?
Thy promiſes are like Adonis Garden,
That one day bloom’d, and fruitfull were the next.
France, triumph in thy glorious Propheteſſe,
Recouer’d is the Towne of Orleance,
More bleſſed hap did ne’re befall our State.

speech.speaker: Reigneir.
speech.line: Why ring not out the Bells alowd,
Throughout the Towne?
Dolphin command the Citizens make Bonﬁres,
And feaſt and banquet in the open ſtreets,
To celebrate the ioy that God hath giuen vs.

speech.speaker: Alanſ.
speech.line: All France will be repleat with mirth and ioy,
When they ſhall heare how we haue play’d the men.

speech.speaker: Dolph.
speech.line: ‘Tis Ioane, not we, by whom the day is wonne:
For which, I will diuide my Crowne with her,
And all the Prieſts and Fryers in my Realme,
Shall in proceſſion ſing her endleſſe prayſe.
A ſtatelyer Pyramis to her Ile reare,
Then Rhodophe’s or Memphis euer was.
In memorie of her, when ſhe is dead,
Her Aſhes, in an Vrne more precious
Then the rich-iewel’d Coffer of Darius,
Tranſported, ſhall be at high Feſtiuals
Before the Kings and Queenes of France.
No longer on Saint Dennis will we cry,
But Ioane de Puzel ſhall be France’s Saint.
Come in, and let vs Banquet Royally,
After this Golden Day of Viorie.

scene.stagedir: Enter a Sergeant of a Band, with two Sentinels.

speech.speaker: Ser.
speech.line: Sirs, take your places, and be vigilant:
If any noyſe or Souldier you perceiue
Neere to the walles, by ſome apparant ſigne
Let vs haue knowledge at the Court of Guard.

speech.speaker: Sent.
speech.line: Sergeant you ſhall. Thus are poore Seruitors
(When others ſleepe vpon their quiet beds)
Conſtrain’d to watch in darkneſſe, raine, and cold.

scene.stagedir: Enter Talbot, Bedford, and Burgundy, with ſcaling Ladders: Their Drummes beating a Dead March.

speech.speaker: Tal.
speech.line: Lord Regent, and redoubted Burgundy,
By whoſe approach, the Regions of Artoys,
Wallon, and Picardy, are friends to vs:
This happy night, the Frenchmen are ſecure,
Hauing all day carows’d and banquetted,
Embrace we then this opportunitie,
As ﬁtting beſt to quittance their deceite,
Contriu’d by Art, and balefull Sorcerie.

speech.speaker: Bed.
speech.line: Coward of France, how much he wrongs his fame,
Diſpairing of his owne armes fortitude,
To ioyne with Witches, and the helpe of Hell.

speech.speaker: Bur.
speech.line: Traitors haue neuer other company.
But what’s that Puzell whom they tearme ſo pure?

speech.speaker: Tal.
speech.line: A Maid, they ſay.

speech.speaker: Bed.
speech.line: A Maid? And be ſo martiall?

speech.speaker: Bur.
speech.line: Pray God ſhe proue not maſculine ere long:
If vnderneath the Standard of the French
She carry Armour, as ſhe hath begun.

speech.speaker: Tal.
speech.line: Well, let them praiſe and conuerſe with ſpirits.
God is our Fortreſſe, in whoſe conquering name
Let vs reſolue to ſcale their ﬂinty bulwarkes.

speech.speaker: Bed.
speech.line: Aſcend braue Talbot, we will follow thee.

speech.speaker: Tal.
speech.line: Not altogether: Better farre I gueſſe,
That we do make our entrance ſeuerall wayes:
That if it chance the one of vs do faile,
The other yet may riſe againſt their force.

speech.speaker: Bed.
speech.line: Agreed; Ile to yond corner.

speech.speaker: Bur.
speech.line: And I to this.

speech.speaker: Tal.
speech.line: And heere will Talbot mount, or make his graue.
Now Salisbury, for thee and for the right
Of Engliſh Henry, ſhall this night appeare
How much in duty, I am bound to both.

speech.speaker: Sent.
speech.line: Arme, arme, the enemy doth make aſſault.

scene.stagedir: The French leape ore the walles in their ſhirts. Enter ſeuerall wayes, Baſtard, Alanſon, Reignier, halfe ready, and halfe vnready.

speech.speaker: Alan.
speech.line: How now my Lords? what all vnreadie ſo?

speech.speaker: Baſt.
speech.line: Vnready? I and glad we ſcap’d ſo well.

speech.speaker: Reig.
speech.line: ’Twas time (I trow) to wake and leaue our beds,
Hearing Alarums at our Chamber doores.

speech.speaker: Alan.
speech.line: Of all exploits ſince ﬁrſt I follow’d Armes,
Nere heard I of a warlike enterprize
More venturous, or deſperate then this.

speech.speaker: Baſt.
speech.line: I thinke this Talbot be a Fiend of Hell.

speech.speaker: Reig.
speech.line: If not of Hell, the Heauens ſure fauour him.

speech.speaker: Alanſ.
speech.line: Here commeth Charles, I maruell how he ſped?

speech.speaker: Baſt.
speech.line: Tut, holy Ioane was his defenſiue Guard.

speech.speaker: Charl.
speech.line: Is this thy cunning, thou deceitfull Dame?
Didſt thou at ﬁrſt, to ﬂatter vs withall,
Make vs partakers of a little gayne,
That now our loſſe might be ten times ſo much?

speech.speaker: Ioane.
speech.line: Wherefore is Charles impatient with his friend?
At all times will you haue my Power alike?
Sleeping or waking, muſt I ſtill preuayle,
Or will you blame and lay the fault on me?
Improuident Souldiors, had your Watch been good,
This ſudden Miſchiefe neuer could haue falne.

speech.speaker: Charl.
speech.line: Duke of Alanſon, this was your default,
That being Captaine of the Watch to Night,
Did looke no better to that weightie Charge.

speech.speaker: Alanſ.
speech.line: Had all your Quarters been as ſafely kept,
As that whereof I had the gouernment,
We had not beene thus ſhamefully ſurpriz’d.

speech.speaker: Baſt.
speech.line: Mine was ſecure.

speech.speaker: Reig.
speech.line: And ſo was mine, my Lord.

speech.speaker: Charl.
speech.line: And for my ſelfe, moſt part of all this Night
Within her Quarter, and mine owne Precin,
I was imploy’d in paſſing to and fro,
About relieuing of the Centinels.
Then how, or which way, ſhould they ﬁrſt breake in?

speech.speaker: Ioane.
speech.line: Queſtion (my Lords) no further of the caſe,
How or which way; ‘tis ſure they found ſome place,
But weakely guarded, where the breach was made:
And now there reſts no other ſhift but this,
To gather our Souldiors, ſcatter’d and diſperc’t,
And lay new Plat-formes to endammage them.

scene.stagedir: Alarum. Enter a Souldier, crying, a Talbot, a Talbot: they ﬂye, leauing their Clothes behind.

speech.speaker: Sould.
speech.line: Ile be ſo bold to take what they haue left:
The Cry of Talbot ſerues me for a Sword,
For I haue loaden me with many Spoyles,
Vſing no other Weapon but his Name.

speech.speaker: Bedf.
speech.line: The Day begins to breake, and Night is ﬂed,
Whoſe pitchy Mantle ouer-vayl’d the Earth.
Here ſound Retreat, and ceaſe our hot purſuit.

speech.speaker: Talb.
speech.line: Bring forth the Body of old Salisbury,
And here aduance it in the Market-Place,
The middle Centure of this curſed Towne.
Now haue I pay’d my Vow vnto his Soule:
For euery drop of blood was drawne from him,
There hath at leaſt ﬁue Frenchmen dyed to night.
And that hereafter Ages may behold
What ruine happened in reuenge of him,
Within their chiefeſt Temple Ile ere
A Tombe, wherein his Corps ſhall be interr’d:
Vpon the which, that euery one may reade,
Shall be engrau’d the ſacke of Orleance,
The trecherous manner of his mournefull death,
And what a terror he had beene to France.
But Lords, in all our bloudy Maſſacre,
I muſe we met not with the Dolphins Grace,
His new-come Champion, vertuous Ioane of Acre,
Nor any of his falſe Confederates.

speech.speaker: Bedf.
speech.line: ‘Tis thought Lord Talbot, when the ﬁght began,
Rows’d on the ſudden from their drowſie Beds,
They did amongſt the troupes of armed men,
Leape o’re the Walls for refuge in the ﬁeld.

speech.speaker: Burg.
speech.line: My ſelfe, as farre as I could well diſcerne,
For ſmoake, and duskie vapours of the night,
Am ſure I ſcar’d the Dolphin and his Trull,
When Arme in Arme they both came ſwiftly running,
Like to a payre of louing Turtle-Doues,
That could not liue aſunder day or night.
After that things are ſet in order here,
Wee’le follow them with all the power we haue.

speech.speaker: Meſſ.
speech.line: All hayle, my Lords: which of this Princely trayne
Call ye the Warlike Talbot, for his As
So much applauded through the Realme of France?

speech.speaker: Talb.
speech.line: Here is the Talbot, who would ſpeak with him?

speech.speaker: Meſſ.
speech.line: The vertuous Lady, Counteſſe of Ouergne,
With modeſtie admiring thy Renowne,
By me entreats (great Lord) thou would’ſt vouchſafe
To viſit her poore Caſtle where ſhe lyes,
That ſhe may boaſt ſhe hath beheld the man,
Whoſe glory ﬁlls the World with lowd report.

speech.speaker: Burg.
speech.line: Is it euen ſo? Nay, then I ſee our Warres
Will turne vnto a peacefull Comick ſport,
When Ladyes craue to be encountred with.
You may not (my Lord) deſpiſe her gentle ſuit.

speech.speaker: Talb.
speech.line: Ne’re truſt me then: for when a World of men
Could not preuayle with all their Oratorie,
Yet hath a Womans kindneſſe ouer-rul’d:
And therefore tell her, I returne great thankes,
And in ſubmiſſion will attend on her.
Will not your Honors beare me company?

speech.speaker: Bedf.
speech.line: No, truly, ‘tis more then manners will:
And I haue heard it ſayd, Vnbidden Gueſts
Are often welcommeſt when they are gone.

speech.speaker: Talb.
speech.line: Well then, alone (ſince there’s no remedie)
I meane to proue this Ladyes courteſie.
Come hither Captaine, you perceiue my minde.

speech.speaker: Capt.
speech.line: I doe my Lord, and meane accordingly.

speech.speaker: Count.
speech.line: Porter, remember what I gaue in charge,
And when you haue done ſo, bring the Keyes to me.
Port. Madame, I will.

speech.speaker: Count.
speech.line: The Plot is layd, if all things fall out right,
I ſhall as famous be by this exploit,
As Scythian Tomyris by Cyrus death.
Great is the rumour of this dreadfull Knight,
And his atchieuements of no leſſe account:
Faine would mine eyes be witneſſe with mine eares,
To giue their cenſure of theſe rare reports.

speech.speaker: Meſſ.
speech.line: Madame, according as your Ladyſhip deſir’d,
By Meſſage crau’d, ſo is Lord Talbot come.

speech.speaker: Count.
speech.line: And he is welcome: what? is this the man?

speech.speaker: Meſſ.
speech.line: Madame, it is.

speech.speaker: Count.
speech.line: Is this the Scourge of France?
Is this the Talbot, ſo much fear’d abroad?
That with his Name the Mothers ſtill their Babes?
I ſee Report is fabulous and falſe.
I thought I ſhould haue ſeene ſome Hercules,
A ſecond Heor, for his grim aſpe,
And large proportion of his ſtrong knit Limbes.
Alas, this is a Child, a ſilly Dwarfe:
It cannot be, this weake and writhled ſhrimpe
Should ſtrike ſuch terror to his Enemies.

speech.speaker: Talb.
speech.line: Madame, I haue beene bold to trouble you:
But ſince your Ladyſhip is not at leyſure,
Ile ſort ſome other time to viſit you.

speech.speaker: Count.
speech.line: What meanes he now?
Goe aske him, whither he goes?

speech.speaker: Meſſ.
speech.line: Stay my Lord Talbot, for my Lady craues,
To know the cauſe of your abrupt departure?

speech.speaker: Talb.
speech.line: Marry, for that ſhee’s in a wrong beleefe,
I goe to certiﬁe her Talbot’s here.

speech.speaker: Count.
speech.line: If thou be he, then art thou Priſoner.

speech.speaker: Talb.
speech.line: Priſoner? to whom?

speech.speaker: Count.
speech.line: To me, blood-thirſtie Lord:
And for that cauſe I trayn’d thee to my Houſe.
Long time thy ſhadow hath been thrall to me,
For in my Gallery thy Piure hangs:
But now the ſubſtance ſhall endure the like,
And I will chayne theſe Legges and Armes of thine,
That haſt by Tyrannie theſe many yeeres
Waſted our Countrey, ſlaine our Citizens,
And ſent our Sonnes and Husbands captiuate.

speech.speaker: Talb.
speech.line: Ha, ha, ha.

speech.speaker: Count.
speech.line: Laugheſt thou Wretch?
Thy mirth ſhall turne to moane.

speech.speaker: Talb.
speech.line: I laugh to ſee your Ladyſhip ſo fond,
To thinke, that you haue ought but Talbots ſhadow,
Whereon to praiſe your ſeueritie.

speech.speaker: Count.
speech.line: Why? art not thou the man?

speech.speaker: Talb.
speech.line: I am indeede.

speech.speaker: Count.
speech.line: Then haue I ſubſtance too.

speech.speaker: Talb.
speech.line: No, no, I am but ſhadow of my ſelfe:
You are deceiu’d, my ſubſtance is not here;
For what you ſee, is but the ſmalleſt part,
And leaſt proportion of Humanitie:
I tell you Madame, were the whole Frame here,
It is of ſuch a ſpacious loftie pitch,
Your Roofe were not ſufﬁcient to contayn’t.

speech.speaker: Count.
speech.line: This is a Riddling Merchant for the nonce,
He will be here, and yet he is not here:
How can theſe contrarieties agree?

speech.speaker: Talb.
speech.line: That will I ſhew you preſently.
speech.stagedir: Winds his Horne, Drummes ſtrike vp, a Peale of Ordenance: Enter Souldiors.
speech.line: How ſay you Madame? are you now perſwaded,
That Talbot is but ſhadow of himſelfe?
Theſe are his ſubſtance, ſinewes, armes, and ſtrength,
With which he yoaketh your rebellious Neckes,
Razeth your Cities, and ſubuerts your Townes,
And in a moment makes them deſolate.

speech.speaker: Count.
speech.line: Viorious Talbot, pardon my abuſe,
I ﬁnde thou art no leſſe then Fame hath bruited,
And more then may be gathered by thy ſhape.
Let my preſumption not prouoke thy wrath,
For I am ſorry, that with reuerence
I did not entertaine thee as thou art.

speech.speaker: Talb.
speech.line: Be not diſmay’d, faire Lady, nor miſconſter
The minde of Talbot, as you did miſtake
The outward compoſition of his body.
What you haue done, hath not offended me:
Nor other ſatisfaion doe I craue,
But onely with your patience, that we may
Taſte of your Wine, and ſee what Cates you haue,
For Souldiers ſtomacks alwayes ſerue them well.

speech.speaker: Count.
speech.line: With all my heart, and thinke me honored,
To feaſt ſo great a Warrior in my Houſe.

scene.stagedir: Enter Richard Plantagenet, Warwick, Somerſet, Poole, and others.

speech.speaker: Yorke.
speech.line: Great Lords and Gentlemen,
What meanes this ſilence?
Dare no man anſwer in a Caſe of Truth?

speech.speaker: Suff.
speech.line: Within the Temple Hall we were too lowd,
The Garden here is more conuenient.

speech.speaker: York.
speech.line: Then ſay at once, if I maintain’d the Truth:
Or elſe was wrangling Somerſet in th’ error?

speech.speaker: Suff.
speech.line: Faith I haue beene a Truant in the Law,
And neuer yet could frame my will to it,
And therefore frame the Law vnto my will.

speech.speaker: Som.
speech.line: Iudge you, my Lord of Warwicke, then be —
tweene vs.

speech.speaker: War.
speech.line: Between two Hawks, which ﬂyes the higher pitch,
Between two Dogs, which hath the deeper mouth,
Between two Blades, which beares the better temper,
Between two Horſes, which doth beare him beſt,
Between two Girles, which hath the merryeſt eye,
I haue perhaps ſome ſhallow ſpirit of Iudgement:
But in theſe nice ſharpe Quillets of the Law,
Good faith I am no wiſer then a Daw.

speech.speaker: York.
speech.line: Tut, tut, here is a mannerly forbearance:
The truth appeares ſo naked on my ſide,
That any purblind eye may ﬁnd it out.

speech.speaker: Som.
speech.line: And on my ſide it is ſo well apparrell’d,
So cleare, ſo ſhining, and ſo euident,
That it will glimmer through a blind-mans eye.

speech.speaker: York.
speech.line: Since you are tongue-ty’d, and ſo loth to ſpeake,
In dumbe ſigniﬁcants proclayme your thoughts:
Let him that is a true-borne Gentleman,
And ſtands vpon the honor of his birth,
If he ſuppoſe that I haue pleaded truth,
From off this Bryer pluck a white Roſe with me.

speech.speaker: Som.
speech.line: Let him that is no Coward, nor no Flatterer,
But dare maintaine the partie of the truth,
Pluck a red Roſe from off this Thorne with me.

speech.speaker: War.
speech.line: I loue no Colours: and without all colour
Of baſe inſinuating ﬂatterie,
I pluck this white Roſe with Plantagenet.

speech.speaker: Suff.
speech.line: I pluck this red Roſe, with young Somerſet,
And ſay withall, I thinke he held the right.

speech.speaker: Vernon.
speech.line: Stay Lords and Gentlemen, and pluck no more
Till you conclude, that he vpon whoſe ſide
The feweſt Roſes are cropt from the Tree,
Shall yeeld the other in the right opinion.

speech.speaker: Som.
speech.line: Good Maſter Vernon, it is well obieed:
If I haue feweſt, I ſubſcribe in ſilence.

speech.speaker: York.
speech.line: And I.

speech.speaker: Vernon.
speech.line: Then for the truth, and plainneſſe of the Caſe,
I pluck this pale and Maiden Bloſſome here,
Giuing my Verdi on the white Roſe ſide.

speech.speaker: Som.
speech.line: Prick not your ﬁnger as you pluck it off,
Leaſt bleeding, you doe paint the white Roſe red,
And fall on my ſide ſo againſt your will.

speech.speaker: Vernon.
speech.line: If I, my Lord, for my opinion bleed,
Opinion ſhall be Surgeon to my hurt,
And keepe me on the ſide where ſtill I am.

speech.speaker: Som.
speech.line: Well, well, come on, who elſe?

speech.speaker: Lawyer.
speech.line: Vnleſſe my Studie and my Bookes be falſe,
The argument you held, was wrong in you;
In ſigne whereof, I pluck a white Roſe too.

speech.speaker: Yorke.
speech.line: Now Somerſet, where is your argument?

speech.speaker: Som.
speech.line: Here in my Scabbard, meditating, that
Shall dye your white Roſe in a bloody red.

speech.speaker: York.
speech.line: Meane time your cheeks do counterfeit our Roſes:
For pale they looke with feare, as witneſſing
The truth on our ſide.

speech.speaker: Som.
speech.line: No Plantagenet:
Tis not for feare, but anger, that thy cheekes
Bluſh for pure ſhame, to counterfeit our Roſes,
And yet thy tongue will not confeſſe thy error.

speech.speaker: Yorke.
speech.line: Hath not thy Roſe a Canker, Somerſet?

speech.speaker: Som.
speech.line: Hath not thy Roſe a Thorne, Plantagenet?

speech.speaker: Yorke.
speech.line: I, ſharpe and piercing to maintaine his truth,
Whiles thy conſuming Canker eates his falſehood.

speech.speaker: Som.
speech.line: Well, Ile ﬁnd friends to weare my bleeding Roſes,
That ſhall maintaine what I haue ſaid is true,
Where falſe Plantagenet dare not be ſeene.

speech.speaker: Yorke.
speech.line: Now by this Maiden Bloſſome in my hand,
I ſcorne thee and thy faſhion, peeuiſh Boy.

speech.speaker: Suff.
speech.line: Turne not thy ſcornes this way, Plantagenet.

speech.speaker: Yorke.
speech.line: Prowd Poole, I will, and ſcorne both him and
thee.

speech.speaker: Suff.
speech.line: Ile turne my part thereof into thy throat.

speech.speaker: Som.
speech.line: Away, away, good William de la Poole,
We grace the Yeoman, by conuerſing with him.

speech.speaker: Warw.
speech.line: Now by Gods will thou wrong’ſt him, Somerſet:
His Grandfather was Lyonel Duke of Clarence,
Third Sonne to the third Edward King of England:
Spring Creſtleſſe Yeomen from ſo deepe a Root?

speech.speaker: Yorke.
speech.line: He beares him on the place’s Priuiledge,
Or durſt not for his crauen heart ſay thus.

speech.speaker: Som.
speech.line: By him that made me, Ile maintaine my words
On any Plot of Ground in Chriſtendome.
Was not thy Father, Richard, Earle of Cambridge,
For Treaſon executed in our late Kings dayes?
And by his Treaſon, ſtand’ſt not thou attainted,
Corrupted, and exempt from ancient Gentry?
His Treſpas yet liues guiltie in thy blood,
And till thou be reſtor’d, thou art a Yeoman.

speech.speaker: Yorke.
speech.line: My Father was attached, not attainted,
Condemn’d to dye for Treaſon, but no Traytor;
And that Ile proue on better men then Somerſet,
Were growing time once ripened to my will.
For your partaker Poole, and you your ſelfe,
Ile note you in my Booke of Memorie,
To ſcourge you for this apprehenſion:
Looke to it well, and ſay you are well warn’d.

speech.speaker: Som.
speech.line: Ah, thou ſhalt ﬁnde vs ready for thee ſtill:
And know vs by theſe Colours for thy Foes,
For theſe, my friends in ſpight of thee ſhall weare.

speech.speaker: Yorke.
speech.line: And by my Soule, this pale and angry Roſe,
As Cognizance of my blood-drinking hate,
Will I for euer, and my Faion weare,
Vntill it wither with me to my Graue,
Or ﬂouriſh to the height of my Degree.

speech.speaker: Suff.
speech.line: Goe forward, and be choak’d with thy ambition:
And ſo farwell, vntill I meet thee next.

speech.speaker: Som.
speech.line: Haue with thee Poole: Farwell ambitious Ri-
chard.

speech.speaker: Yorke.
speech.line: How I am brau’d, and muſt perforce endure
it?

speech.speaker: Warw.
speech.line: This blot that they obie againſt your Houſe,
Shall be whipt out in the next Parliament,
Call’d for the Truce of Wincheſter and Glouceſter:
And if thou be not then created Yorke,
I will not liue to be accounted Warwicke.
Meane time, in ſignall of my loue to thee,
Againſt prowd Somerſet, and William Poole,
Will I vpon thy partie weare this Roſe.
And here I prophecie: this brawle to day,
Growne to this faion in the Temple Garden,
Shall ſend betweene the Red-Roſe and the White,
A thouſand Soules to Death and deadly Night.

speech.speaker: Yorke.
speech.line: Good Maſter Vernon, I am bound to you,
That you on my behalfe would pluck a Flower.

speech.speaker: Ver.
speech.line: In your behalfe ſtill will I weare the ſame.

speech.speaker: Lawyer.
speech.line: And ſo will I.

speech.speaker: Yorke.
speech.line: Thankes gentle.
Come, let vs foure to Dinner: I dare ſay,
This Quarrell will drinke Blood another day.

scene.stagedir: Enter Mortimer, brought in a Chayre, and Iaylors.

speech.speaker: Mort.
speech.line: Kind Keepers of my weake decaying Age,
Let dying Mortimer here reſt himſelfe.
Euen like a man new haled from the Wrack,
So fare my Limbes with long Impriſonment:
And theſe gray Locks, the Purſuiuants of death,
Neſtor-like aged, in an Age of Care,
Argue the end of Edmund Mortimer.
Theſe Eyes like Lampes, whoſe waſting Oyle is ſpent,
Waxe dimme, as drawing to their Exigent.
Weake Shoulders, ouer-borne with burthening Griefe,
And pyth-leſſe Armes, like to a withered Vine,
That droupes his ſappe-leſſe Branches to the ground.
Yet are theſe Feet, whoſe ſtrength-leſſe ſtay is numme,
(Vnable to ſupport this Lumpe of Clay)
Swift-winged with deſire to get a Graue,
As witting I no other comfort haue.
But tell me, Keeper, will my Nephew come?

speech.speaker: Keeper.
speech.line: Richard Plantagenet, my Lord, will come:
We ſent vnto the Temple, vnto his Chamber,
And anſwer was return’d, that he will come.

speech.speaker: Mort.
speech.line: Enough: my Soule ſhall then be ſatisﬁed.
Poore Gentleman, his wrong doth equall mine.
Since Henry Monmouth ﬁrſt began to reigne,
Before whoſe Glory I was great in Armes,
This loathſome ſequeſtration haue I had;
And euen ſince then, hath Richard beene obſcur’d,
Depriu’d of Honor and Inheritance.
But now, the Arbitrator of Deſpaires,
Iuſt Death, kinde Vmpire of mens miſeries,
With ſweet enlargement doth diſmiſſe me hence:
I would his troubles likewiſe were expir’d,
That ſo he might recouer what was loſt.

speech.speaker: Keeper.
speech.line: My Lord, your louing Nephew now is come.

speech.speaker: Mor.
speech.line: Richard Plantagenet, my friend, is he come?

speech.speaker: Rich.
speech.line: I, Noble Vnckle, thus ignobly vs’d,
Your Nephew, late deſpiſed Richard, comes.

speech.speaker: Mort.
speech.line: Dire mine Armes, I may embrace his Neck,
And in his Boſome ſpend my latter gaſpe.
Oh tell me when my Lippes doe touch his Cheekes,
That I may kindly giue one fainting Kiſſe.
And now declare ſweet Stem from Yorkes great Stock,
Why didſt thou ſay of late thou wert deſpis’d?

speech.speaker: Rich.
speech.line: Firſt, leane thine aged Back againſt mine Arme,
And in that eaſe, Ile tell thee my Diſeaſe.
This day in argument vpon a Caſe,
Some words there grew ’twixt Somerſet and me:
Among which tearmes, he vs’d his lauiſh tongue,
And did vpbrayd me with my Fathers death;
Which obloquie ſet barres before my tongue,
Elſe with the like I had requited him.
Therefore good Vnckle, for my Fathers ſake,
In honor of a true Plantagenet,
And for Alliance ſake, declare the cauſe
My Father, Earle of Cambridge, loſt his Head.

speech.speaker: Mort.
speech.line: That cauſe (faire Nephew) that impriſon’d me,
And hath detayn’d me all my ﬂowring Youth,
Within a loathſome Dungeon, there to pyne,
Was curſed Inſtrument of his deceaſe.

speech.speaker: Rich.
speech.line: Diſcouer more at large what cauſe that was,
For I am ignorant, and cannot gueſſe.

speech.speaker: Mort.
speech.line: I will, if that my fading breath permit,
And Death approach not, ere my Tale be done.
Henry the Fourth, Grandfather to this King,
Depos’d his Nephew Richard, Edwards Sonne,
The ﬁrſt begotten, and the lawfull Heire
Of Edward King, the Third of that Deſcent.
During whoſe Reigne, the Percies of the North,
Finding his Vſurpation moſt vniuſt,
Endeuour’d my aduancement to the Throne.
The reaſon mou’d theſe Warlike Lords to this,
Was, for that (young Richard thus remou’d,
Leauing no Heire begotten of his Body)
I was the next by Birth and Parentage:
For by my Mother, I deriued am
From Lionel Duke of Clarence, third Sonne
To King Edward the Third; whereas hee,
From Iohn of Gaunt doth bring his Pedigree,
Being but fourth of that Heroick Lyne.
But marke: as in this haughtie great attempt,
They laboured, to plant the rightfull Heire,
I loſt my Libertie, and they their Liues.
Long after this, when Henry the Fift
(Succeeding his Father Bullingbrooke) did reigne;
Thy Father, Earle of Cambridge, then deriu’d
From famous Edmund Langley, Duke of Yorke,
Marrying my Siſter, that thy Mother was;
Againe, in pitty of my hard diſtreſſe,
Leuied an Army, weening to redeeme,
And haue inſtall’d me in the Diademe:
But as the reſt, ſo fell that Noble Earle,
And was beheaded. Thus the Mortimers,
In whom the Title reſted, were ſuppreſt.

speech.speaker: Rich.
speech.line: Of which, my Lord, your Honor is the laſt.

speech.speaker: Mort.
speech.line: True; and thou ſeeſt, that I no Iſſue haue,
And that my fainting words doe warrant death:
Thou art my Heire; the reſt, I wiſh thee gather:
But yet be wary in thy ſtudious care.

speech.speaker: Rich.
speech.line: Thy graue admoniſhments preuayle with me:
But yet me thinkes, my Fathers execution
Was nothing leſſe then bloody Tyranny.

speech.speaker: Mort.
speech.line: With ſilence, Nephew, be thou pollitick,
Strong ﬁxed is the Houſe of Lancaſter,
And like a Mountaine, not to be remou’d.
But now thy Vnckle is remouing hence,
As Princes doe their Courts, when they are cloy’d
With long continuance in a ſetled place.

speech.speaker: Rich.
speech.line: O Vnckle, would ſome part of my young yeeres
Might but redeeme the paſſage of your Age.

speech.speaker: Mort.
speech.line: Thou do’ſt then wrong me, as ý ſlaughterer doth,
Which giueth many Wounds, when one will kill.
Mourne not, except thou ſorrow for my good,
Onely giue order for my Funerall.
And ſo farewell, and faire be all thy hopes,
And proſperous be thy Life in Peace and Warre.

speech.speaker: Rich.
speech.line: And Peace, no Warre, befall thy parting Soule.
In Priſon haſt thou ſpent a Pilgrimage,
And like a Hermite ouer-paſt thy dayes.
Well, I will locke his Councell in my Breſt,
And what I doe imagine, let that reſt.
Keepers conuey him hence, and I my ſelfe
Will ſee his Buryall better then his Life.
Here dyes the duskie Torch of Mortimer,
Choakt with Ambition of the meaner ſort.
And for thoſe Wrongs, thoſe bitter Iniuries,
Which Somerſet hath offer’d to my Houſe,
I doubt not, but with Honor to redreſſe.
And therefore haſte I to the Parliament,
Eyther to be reſtored to my Blood,
Or make my will th’ aduantage of my good.

scene.stagedir: Flouriſh. Enter King, Exeter, Gloſter, Wincheſter, Warwick. Somerſet, Suﬀolk, Richard Plantagenet. Gloſter oﬀers to put vp a Bill: Wincheſter ſnatches it, teares it.

speech.speaker: Winch.
speech.line: Com’ſt thou with deepe premeditated Lines?
With written Pamphlets, ſtudiouſly deuis’d?
Humfrey of Gloſter, if thou canſt accuſe,
Or ought intend’ſt to lay vnto my charge,
Doe it without inuention, ſuddenly,
As I with ſudden, and extemporall ſpeech,
Purpoſe to anſwer what thou canſt obie.

speech.speaker: Glo.
speech.line: Preſumptuous Prieſt, this place cōmands my patiēce,
Or thou ſhould’ſt ﬁnde thou haſt dis-honor’d me.
Thinke not, although in Writing I preferr’d
The manner of thy vile outragious Crymes,
That therefore I haue forg’d, or am not able
Verbatim to rehearſe the Methode of my Penne.
No Prelate, ſuch is thy audacious wickedneſſe,
Thy lewd, peſtiferous, and diſſentious prancks,
As very Infants prattle of thy pride.
Thou art a moſt pernitious Vſurer,
Froward by nature, Enemie to Peace,
Laſciuious, wanton, more then well beſeemes
A man of thy Profeſſion, and Degree.
And for thy Trecherie, what’s more manifeſt?
In that thou layd’ſt a Trap to take my Life,
As well at London Bridge, as at the Tower.
Beſide, I feare me, if thy thoughts were ſifted,
The King, thy Soueraigne, is not quite exempt
From enuious mallice of thy ſwelling heart.

speech.speaker: Winch.
speech.line: Gloſter, I doe deﬁe thee. Lords vouchſafe
To giue me hearing what I ſhall reply.
If I were couetous, ambitious, or peruerſe,
As he will haue me: how am I ſo poore?
Or how haps it, I ſeeke not to aduance
Or rayſe my ſelfe? but keepe my wonted Calling.
And for Diſſention, who preferreth Peace
More then I doe? except I be prouok’d.
No, my good Lords, it is not that offends,
It is not that, that hath incens’d the Duke:
It is becauſe no one ſhould ſway but hee,
No one, but hee, ſhould be about the King;
And that engenders Thunder in his breaſt,
And makes him rore theſe Accuſations forth.
But he ſhall know I am as good.

speech.speaker: Glost.
speech.line: As good?
Thou Baſtard of my Grandfather.

speech.speaker: Winch.
speech.line: I, Lordly Sir: for what are you, I pray,
But one imperious in anothers Throne?

speech.speaker: Gloſt.
speech.line: Am I not Proteor, ſawcie Prieſt?

speech.speaker: Winch.
speech.line: And am not I a Prelate of the Church?

speech.speaker: Glost.
speech.line: Yes, as an Out-law in a Caſtle keepes,
And vſeth it, to patronage his Theft.

speech.speaker: Winch.
speech.line: Vnreuerent Gloceſter.

speech.speaker: Gloſt.
speech.line: Thou art reuerent,
Touching thy Spirituall Funion, not thy Life.

speech.speaker: Winch.
speech.line: Rome ſhall remedie this.

speech.speaker: Warw.
speech.line: Roame thither then.
My Lord, it were your dutie to forbeare.

speech.speaker: Som.
speech.line: I, ſee the Biſhop be not ouer-borne:
Me thinkes my Lord ſhould be Religious,
And know the Ofﬁce that belongs to ſuch.

speech.speaker: Warw.
speech.line: Me thinkes his Lordſhip ſhould be humbler,
It ﬁtteth not a Prelate ſo to plead.

speech.speaker: Som.
speech.line: Yes, when his holy State is toucht ſo neere.

speech.speaker: Warw.
speech.line: State holy, or vnhallow’d, what of that?
Is not his Grace Proteor to the King?

speech.speaker: Rich.
speech.line: Plantagenet I ſee muſt hold his tongue,
Leaſt it be ſaid, Speake Sirrha when you ſhould:
Muſt your bold Verdi enter talke with Lords?
Elſe would I haue a ﬂing at Wincheſter.

speech.speaker: King.
speech.line: Vnckles of Gloſter, and of Wincheſter,
The ſpeciall Watch-men of our Engliſh Weale,
I would preuayle, if Prayers might preuayle,
To ioyne your hearts in loue and amitie.
Oh, what a Scandall is it to our Crowne,
That two ſuch Noble Peeres as ye ſhould iarre?
Beleeue me, Lords, my tender yeeres can tell,
Ciuill diſſention is a viperous Worme,
That gnawes the Bowels of the Common-wealth.

scene.stagedir: A noyſe within, Downe with the Tawny-Coats.

speech.speaker: King.
speech.line: What tumult’s this?

speech.speaker: Warw.
speech.line: An Vprore, I dare warrant,
Begun through malice of the Biſhops men.

speech.speaker: Maior.
speech.line: Oh my good Lords, and vertuous Henry,
Pitty the Citie of London, pitty vs:
The Biſhop, and the Duke of Gloſters men,
Forbidden late to carry any Weapon,
Haue ﬁll’d their Pockets full of peeble ſtones;
And banding themſelues in contrary parts,
Doe pelt ſo faſt at one anothers Pate,
That many haue their giddy braynes knockt out:
Our Windowes are broke downe in euery Street,
And we, for feare, compell’d to ſhut our Shops.

scene.stagedir: Enter in skirmiſh with bloody Pates.

speech.speaker: King.
speech.line: We charge you, on allegeance to our ſelfe,
To hold your ſlaughtring hands, and keepe the Peace:
Pray’ Vnckle Gloſter mittigate this ſtrife.

speech.speaker: 1. Seruing.
speech.line: Nay, if we be forbidden Stones, wee’le fall
to it with our Teeth.

speech.speaker: 2. Seruing.
speech.line: Doe what ye dare, we are as reſolute.

speech.speaker: Gloſt.
speech.line: You of my houſehold, leaue this peeuiſh broyle,
And ſet this vnaccuſtom’d ﬁght aſide.

speech.speaker: 3. Seru.
speech.line: My Lord, we know your Grace to be a man
Iuſt, and vpright; and for your Royall Birth,
Inferior to none, but to his Maieſtie:
And ere that we will ſuffer ſuch a Prince,
So kinde a Father of the Common-weale,
To be diſgraced by an Inke-horne Mate,
Wee and our Wiues and Children all will ﬁght,
And haue our bodyes ſlaughtred by thy foes.

speech.speaker: 1. Seru.
speech.line: I, and the very parings of our Nayles
Shall pitch a Field when we are dead.

speech.speaker: Gloſt.
speech.line: Stay, ſtay, I ſay:
And if you loue me, as you ſay you doe,
Let me perſwade you to forbeare a while.

speech.speaker: King.
speech.line: Oh, how this diſcord doth afﬂi my Soule.
Can you, my Lord of Wincheſter, behold
My ſighes and teares, and will not once relent?
Who ſhould be pittifull, if you be not?
Or who ſhould ſtudy to preferre a Peace,
If holy Church-men take delight in broyles?

speech.speaker: Warw.
speech.line: Yeeld my Lord Proteor, yeeld Wincheſter,
Except you meane with obſtinate repulſe
To ſlay your Soueraigne, and deſtroy the Realme.
You ſee what Miſchiefe, and what Murther too,
Hath beene enaed through your enmitie:
Then be at peace, except ye thirſt for blood.

speech.speaker: Winch.
speech.line: He ſhall ſubmit, or I will neuer yeeld.

speech.speaker: Gloſt.
speech.line: Compaſſion on the King commands me ſtoupe,
Or I would ſee his heart out, ere the Prieſt
Should euer get that priuiledge of me.

speech.speaker: Warw.
speech.line: Behold my Lord of Wincheſter, the Duke
Hath baniſht moodie diſcontented fury,
As by his ſmoothed Browes it doth appeare:
Why looke you ſtill ſo ſterne, and tragicall?

speech.speaker: Gloſt.
speech.line: Here Wincheſter, I offer thee my Hand.

speech.speaker: King.
speech.line: Fie Vnckle Beauford, I haue heard you preach,
That Mallice was a great and grieuous ſinne:
And will not you maintaine the thing you teach?
But proue a chiefe offendor in the ſame.

speech.speaker: Warw.
speech.line: Sweet King: the Biſhop hath a kindly gyrd:
For ſhame my Lord of Wincheſter relent;
What, ſhall a Child inſtru you what to doe?

speech.speaker: Winch.
speech.line: Well, Duke of Gloſter, I will yeeld to thee
Loue for thy Loue, and Hand for Hand I giue.

speech.speaker: Gloſt.
speech.line: I, but I feare me with a hollow Heart.
See here my Friends and louing Countreymen,
This token ſerueth for a Flagge of Truce,
Betwixt our ſelues, and all our followers:
So helpe me God, as I diſſemble not.

speech.speaker: Winch.
speech.line: So helpe me God, as I intend it not.

speech.speaker: King.
speech.line: Oh louing Vnckle, kinde Duke of Gloſter,
How ioyfull am I made by this Contra.
Away my Maſters, trouble vs no more,
But ioyne in friendſhip, as your Lords haue done.

speech.speaker: 1. Seru.
speech.line: Content, Ile to the Surgeons.

speech.speaker: 2. Seru.
speech.line: And ſo will I.

speech.speaker: 3. Seru.
speech.line: And I will ſee what Phyſick the Tauerne af —
fords.

speech.speaker: Warw.
speech.line: Accept this Scrowle, moſt gracious Soueraigne,
Which in the Right of Richard Plantagenet,
We doe exhibite to your Maieſtie.

speech.speaker: Glo.
speech.line: Well vrg’d, my Lord of Warwick: for ſweet Prince,
And if your Grace marke euery circumſtance,
You haue great reaſon to doe Richard right,
Eſpecially for thoſe occaſions
At Eltam Place I told your Maieſtie.

speech.speaker: King.
speech.line: And thoſe occaſions, Vnckle, were of force:
Therefore my louing Lords, our pleaſure is,
That Richard be reſtored to his Blood.

speech.speaker: Warw.
speech.line: Let Richard be reſtored to his Blood,
So ſhall his Fathers wrongs be recompenc’t.

speech.speaker: Winch.
speech.line: As will the reſt, ſo willeth Wincheſter.

speech.speaker: King.
speech.line: If Richard will be true, not that all alone,
But all the whole Inheritance I giue,
That doth belong vnto the Houſe of Yorke,
From whence you ſpring, by Lineall Deſcent.

speech.speaker: Rich.
speech.line: Thy humble ſeruant vowes obedience,
And humble ſeruice, till the point of death.

speech.speaker: King.
speech.line: Stoope then, and ſet your Knee againſt my Foot,
And in reguerdon of that dutie done,
I gyrt thee with the valiant Sword of Yorke:
Riſe Richard, like a true Plantagenet,
And riſe created Princely Duke of Yorke.

speech.speaker: Rich.
speech.line: And ſo thriue Richard, as thy foes may fall,
And as my dutie ſprings, ſo periſh they,
That grudge one thought againſt your Maieſty.

speech.speaker: All.
speech.line: Welcome high Prince, the mighty Duke of Yorke.

speech.speaker: Som.
speech.line: Periſh baſe Prince, ignoble Duke of Yorke.

speech.speaker: Gloſt.
speech.line: Now will it beſt auaile your Maieſtie,
To croſſe the Seas, and to be Crown’d in France:
The preſence of a King engenders loue
Amongſt his Subies, and his loyall Friends,
As it diſ-animates his Enemies.

speech.speaker: King.
speech.line: When Gloſter ſayes the word, King Henry goes,
For friendly counſaile cuts off many Foes.

speech.speaker: Gloſt.
speech.line: Your Ships alreadie are in readineſſe.

speech.speaker: Exet.
speech.line: I, we may march in England, or in France,
Not ſeeing what is likely to enſue:
This late diſſention growne betwixt the Peeres,
Burnes vnder fained aſhes of forg’d loue,
And will at laſt breake out into a ﬂame,
As feſtred members rot but by degree,
Till bones and ﬂeſh and ſinewes fall away,
So will this baſe and enuious diſcord breed.
And now I feare that fatall Prophecie,
Which in the time of Henry, nam’d the Fift,
Was in the mouth of euery ſucking Babe,
That Henry borne at Monmouth ſhould winne all,
And Henry borne at Windſor, looſe all:
Which is ſo plaine, that Exeter doth wiſh,
His dayes may ﬁniſh, ere that hapleſſe time.

scene.stagedir: Enter Pucell diſguis’d, with foure Souldiors with Sacks vpon their backs.

speech.speaker: Pucell.
speech.line: Theſe are the Citie Gates, the Gates of Roan,
Through which our Pollicy muſt make a breach.
Take heed, be wary how you place your words,
Talke like the vulgar ſort of Market men,
That come to gather Money for their Corne.
If we haue entrance, as I hope we ſhall,
And that we ﬁnde the ſlouthfull Watch but weake,
Ile by a ſigne giue notice to our friends,
That Charles the Dolphin may encounter them.

speech.speaker: Souldier.
speech.line: Our Sacks ſhall be a meane to ſack the City,
And we be Lords and Rulers ouer Roan,
Therefore wee’le knock.

speech.speaker: Watch.
speech.line: Che la.

speech.speaker: Pucell.
speech.line: Peaſauns la pouure gens de Fraunce,
Poore Market folkes that come to ſell their Corne.

speech.speaker: Watch.
speech.line: Enter, goe in, the Market Bell is rung.

speech.speaker: Pucell.
speech.line: Now Roan, Ile ſhake thy Bulwarkes to the
ground.

speech.speaker: Charles.
speech.line: Saint Dennis bleſſe this happy Stratageme,
And once againe wee’le ſleepe ſecure in Roan.

speech.speaker: Baſtard.
speech.line: Here entred Pucell, and her Praiſants:
Now ſhe is there, how will ſhe ſpeciﬁe?
Here is the beſt and ſafeſt paſſage in.

speech.speaker: Reig.
speech.line: By thruſting out a Torch from yonder Tower,
Which once diſcern’d, ſhewes that her meaning is,
No way to that (for weakneſſe) which ſhe entred.

scene.stagedir: Enter Pucell on the top, thruſting out a Torch burning.

speech.speaker: Pucell.
speech.line: Behold, this is the happy Wedding Torch,
That ioyneth Roan vnto her Countreymen,
But burning fatall to the Talbonites.

speech.speaker: Baſtard.
speech.line: See Noble Charles the Beacon of our friend,
The burning Torch in yonder Turret ſtands.

speech.speaker: Charles.
speech.line: Now ſhine it like a Commet of Reuenge,
A Prophet to the fall of all our Foes.

speech.speaker: Reig.
speech.line: Deferre no time, delayes haue dangerous ends,
Enter and cry, the Dolphin, preſently,
And then doe execution on the Watch.

scene.stagedir: An Alarum. Talbot in an Excurſion.

speech.speaker: Talb.
speech.line: France, thou ſhalt rue this Treaſon with thy teares,
If Talbot but ſuruiue thy Trecherie.
Pucell that Witch, that damned Sorcereſſe,
Hath wrought this Helliſh Miſchiefe vnawares,
That hardly we eſcap’t the Pride of France.

scene.stagedir: An Alarum: Excurſions. Bedford brought in ſicke in a Chayre.
Enter Talbot and Burgonie without: within, Pucell, Charles, Baſtard, and Reigneir on the Walls.

speech.speaker: Pucell.
speech.line: God morrow Gallants, want ye Corn for Bread?
I thinke the Duke of Burgonie will faſt,
Before hee’le buy againe at ſuch a rate.
’Twas full of Darnell: doe you like the taſte?

speech.speaker: Burg.
speech.line: Scoffe on vile Fiend, and ſhameleſſe Curtizan,
I truſt ere long to choake thee with thine owne,
And make thee curſe the Harueſt of that Corne.

speech.speaker: Charles.
speech.line: Your Grace may ſtarue (perhaps) before that
time.

speech.speaker: Bedf.
speech.line: Oh let no words, but deedes, reuenge this Trea —
ſon.

speech.speaker: Pucell.
speech.line: What will you doe, good gray-beard?
Breake a Launce, and runne a-Tilt at Death,
Within a Chayre.

speech.speaker: Talb.
speech.line: Foule Fiend of France, and Hag of all deſpight,
Incompaſs’d with thy luſtfull Paramours,
Becomes it thee to taunt his valiant Age,
And twit with Cowardiſe a man halfe dead?
Damſell, Ile haue a bowt with you againe,
Or elſe let Talbot periſh with this ſhame.

speech.speaker: Pucell.
speech.line: Are ye ſo hot, Sir: yet Pucell hold thy peace,
If Talbot doe but Thunder, Raine will follow.
God ſpeed the Parliament: who ſhall be the Speaker?

speech.speaker: Talb.
speech.line: Dare yee come forth, and meet vs in the ﬁeld?

speech.speaker: Pucell.
speech.line: Belike your Lordſhip takes vs then for fooles,
To try if that our owne be ours, or no.

speech.speaker: Talb.
speech.line: I ſpeake not to that rayling Hecate,
But vnto thee Alanſon, and the reſt.
Will ye, like Souldiors, come and ﬁght it out?

speech.speaker: Alanſ.
speech.line: Seignior no.

speech.speaker: Talb.
speech.line: Seignior hang: baſe Muleters of France,
Like Peſant foot-Boyes doe they keepe the Walls,
And dare not take vp Armes, like Gentlemen.

speech.speaker: Pucell.
speech.line: Away Captaines, let’s get vs from the Walls,
For Talbot meanes no goodneſſe by his Lookes.
God b’uy my Lord, we came but to tell you
That wee are here.

speech.speaker: Talb.
speech.line: And there will we be too, ere it be long,
Or elſe reproach be Talbots greateſt fame.
Vow Burgonie, by honor of thy Houſe,
Prickt on by publike Wrongs ſuſtain’d in France,
Either to get the Towne againe, or dye.
And I, as ſure as Engliſh Henry liues,
And as his Father here was Conqueror;
As ſure as in this late betrayed Towne,
Great Cordelions Heart was buryed;
So ſure I ſweare, to get the Towne, or dye.

speech.speaker: Burg.
speech.line: My Vowes are equall partners with thy
Vowes.

speech.speaker: Talb.
speech.line: But ere we goe, regard this dying Prince,
The valiant Duke of Bedford: Come my Lord,
We will beſtow you in ſome better place,
Fitter for ſickneſſe, and for craſie age.

speech.speaker: Bedf.
speech.line: Lord Talbot, doe not ſo diſhonour me:
Here will I ſit, before the Walls of Roan,
And will be partner of your weale or woe.

speech.speaker: Burg.
speech.line: Couragious Bedford, let vs now perſwade you.

speech.speaker: Bedf.
speech.line: Not to be gone from hence: for once I read,
That ſtout Pendragon, in his Litter ſick,
Came to the ﬁeld, and vanquiſhed his foes.
Me thinkes I ſhould reuiue the Souldiors hearts,
Becauſe I euer found them as my ſelfe.

speech.speaker: Talb.
speech.line: Vndaunted ſpirit in a dying breaſt,
Then be it ſo: Heauens keepe old Bedford ſafe.
And now no more adoe, braue Burgonie,
But gather we our Forces out of hand,
And ſet vpon our boaſting Enemie.

scene.stagedir: An Alarum: Excurſions. Enter Sir Iohn Falſtaﬀe, and a Captaine.

speech.speaker: Capt.
speech.line: Whither away Sir Iohn Falſtaﬀe, in ſuch haſte?

speech.speaker: Falſt.
speech.line: Whither away? to ſaue my ſelfe by ﬂight,
We are like to haue the ouerthrow againe.

speech.speaker: Capt.
speech.line: What? will you ﬂye, and leaue Lord Talbot?

speech.speaker: Falſt.
speech.line: I, all the Talbots in the World, to ſaue my life.

speech.speaker: Capt.
speech.line: Cowardly Knight, ill fortune follow thee.

scene.stagedir: Retreat. Excurſions. Pucell, Alanſon, and Charles ﬂye.

speech.speaker: Bedf.
speech.line: Now quiet Soule, depart when Heauen pleaſe,
For I haue ſeene our Enemies ouerthrow.
What is the truſt or ſtrength of fooliſh man?
They that of late were daring with their ſcoffes,
Are glad and faine by ﬂight to ſaue themſelues.

scene.stagedir: Bedford dyes, and is carryed in by two in his Chaire.
An Alarum. Enter Talbot, Burgonie, and the reſt.

speech.speaker: Talb.
speech.line: Loſt, and recouered in a day againe,
This is a double Honor, Burgonie:
Yet Heauens haue glory for this Viorie.

speech.speaker: Burg.
speech.line: Warlike and Martiall Talbot, Burgonie
Inſhrines thee in his heart, and there eres
Thy noble Deeds, as Valors Monuments.

speech.speaker: Talb.
speech.line: Thanks gentle Duke: but where is Pucel now?
I thinke her old Familiar is aſleepe.
Now where’s the Baſtards braues, and Charles his glikes?
What all amort? Roan hangs her head for griefe,
That ſuch a valiant Company are ﬂed.
Now will we take ſome order in the Towne,
Placing therein ſome expert Ofﬁcers,
And then depart to Paris, to the King,
For there young Henry with his Nobles lye.

speech.speaker: Burg.
speech.line: What wills Lord Talbot, pleaſeth Burgonie.

speech.speaker: Talb.
speech.line: But yet before we goe, let’s not forget
The Noble Duke of Bedford, late deceas’d,
But ſee his Exequies fulﬁll’d in Roan.
A brauer Souldier neuer couched Launce,
A gentler Heart did neuer ſway in Court.
But Kings and mightieſt Potentates muſt die,
For that’s the end of humane miſerie.

speech.speaker: Pucell.
speech.line: Diſmay not (Princes) at this accident,
Nor grieue that Roan is ſo recouered:
Care is no cure, but rather corroſiue,
For things that are not to be remedy’d.
Let frantike Talbot triumph for a while,
And like a Peacock ſweepe along his tayle,
Wee’le pull his Plumes, and take away his Trayne,
If Dolphin and the reſt will be but rul’d.

speech.speaker: Charles.
speech.line: We haue been guided by thee hitherto,
And of thy Cunning had no difﬁdence,
One ſudden Foyle ſhall neuer breed diſtruſt.

speech.speaker: Baſtard.
speech.line: Search out thy wit for ſecret pollicies,
And we will make thee famous through the World.

speech.speaker: Alanſ.
speech.line: Wee’le ſet thy Statue in ſome holy place,
And haue thee reuerenc’t like a bleſſed Saint.
Employ thee then, ſweet Virgin, for our good.

speech.speaker: Pucell.
speech.line: Then thus it muſt be, this doth Ioane deuiſe:
By faire perſwaſions, mixt with ſugred words,
We will entice the Duke of Burgonie
To leaue the Talbot, and to follow vs.

speech.speaker: Charles.
speech.line: I marry Sweeting, if we could doe that,
France were no place for Henryes Warriors,
Nor ſhould that Nation boaſt it ſo with vs,
But be extirped from our Prouinces.

speech.speaker: Alanſ.
speech.line: For euer ſhould they be expuls’d from France,
And not haue Title of an Earledome here.

speech.speaker: Pucell.
speech.line: Your Honors ſhall perceiue how I will worke,
To bring this matter to the wiſhed end.
Hearke, by the ſound of Drumme you may perceiue
Their Powers are marching vnto Paris-ward.
There goes the Talbot with his Colours ſpred,
And all the Troupes of Engliſh after him.
Now in the Rereward comes the Duke and his:
Fortune in fauor makes him lagge behinde.
Summon a Parley, we will talke with him.

speech.speaker: Charles.
speech.line: A Parley with the Duke of Burgonie.

speech.speaker: Burg.
speech.line: Who craues a Parley with the Burgonie?

speech.speaker: Pucell.
speech.line: The Princely Charles of France, thy Countrey —
man.

speech.speaker: Burg.
speech.line: What ſay’ſt thou Charles? for I am marching
hence.

speech.speaker: Charles.
speech.line: Speake Pucell, and enchaunt him with thy
words.

speech.speaker: Pucell.
